Posts.Content: Hi there, thanks for the advice. I was given some exercises by the physio nurse at hospital. I am doing them religiously even though it hurts a bit because after the first op they really helped. I saw the surgeon today, he said I should keep doing the exercises and just try to be patient. As you say, it takes time but we will get there. Now I have to concentrate on the chemo that starts In four weeks...I am dreading it! Thanks a lot for your kind words. It is very comforting to talk to people that have gone through similar experiences. Take care. xx
Posts.Title: Pain and discomfort

Posts.Content: Hello, I am sorry you are feeling so much pain today. Your experience sounds really close to mine. My biopsy also turned out two out of three and then I had a second surgery to remove more tissue from the breast and clearance of the lymph nodes remaining. That was two weeks ago. The pain is still quite intense and it is exactly as you described it,dull ache with nipping sensations that are quite strong and intense. Are you trying to do your physio exercises? The doctors and nurses yesterday told me I should keep doing them. That the best thing is to try hard and use your arm as normal as possible. Easier said than done!! But I am giving it a go... I was planning to go bak to work next week for a couple ,of weeks before the chemo starts, now not so sure. We must keep fighting, that's for sure. And some posts here are very encouraging. Take care of yourself. Keep in contact. Gentle hug ;)
Posts.Title: Pain and discomfort

Posts.Content: Hey Louise, I am so glad to hear about your drain being removed. Hopefully it will make things a bit easier for you when moving around... Yesterday went ok, shall I say,although my veins were playing up and I have a big bruise now in my hand to accompany the one still there from the anesthesia last time. Never liked needles very much which is so unfortunate as pretty much everything revolves around needles now! And the waiting game is on again :/ Have a good time at the garden centre. Lovely day for it ;) xxxxxx
Posts.Title: Pain and discomfort

Posts.Content: Hello, yes I think the burning sensation you are getting is normal, mine runs down my arm...it feels like sunburn. And it is a lot to do with the nerves repairing themselves from what I have read here in some posts. Sorry to hear about your wound; it's all about patience this long healing process! And even though it must be uncomfortable to have a drain, as you say, it is better than having the fluid building up inside you. I have this big soft lump under my arm, which I am not sure if it is part of the swelling after surgery or fluid building up...it is confusing because it is still numb so it feels weird anyway. I only had a drain in hospital and it was taken off when they send me home the next day. I am having the scan because I had five out of 28 in total (biopsy+clearance) affected, so no escape ;) I am looking forward to trying the different suggestions for sleeping tonight. What a difference a good night sleep can make! You sound a bit more cheerful today. Take care xxx
Posts.Title: Pain and discomfort

Posts.Content: Hi Angie, thanks for thinking about me! I don't have that feeling exactly but worth mentioning it. I am seeing the oncologist tomorrow to discuss chemo treatment. I will let you know how it goes. Xxx
Posts.Title: Pain and discomfort

Posts.Content: Thank you very much for the info. The bit about lying in bed is really helpful -I would try it tonight. Take care x Louise, how are you keeping? I am going for my CT scan this afternoon. Feeling a little nervous... I hope your pain is a bit better (ish) Take care xxx
Posts.Title: Pain and discomfort

Posts.Content: I was diagnosed with breast cancer in late December. I had a lumpectomy and sentinel node biopsy at the end of January.I have also had total lymph removal from my axilla two weeks ago and I am still in so much pain, barely managing to do my exercises. Is this usual? My first surgery went so well, now that I think back! I was back at work in less than three weeks but now I am doubting I will manage to even go for a walk soon with this pain. Is there something you can suggest to alleviate this? Thanks :)
Posts.Title: Pain and discomfort

Posts.Content: Thank you Angie! I will do so. I know it's early days and there's a long way ahead, but having people around to share the experiences is a great help. Some of the stories here are so strong, inspiring and hopeful... Cheers again for taking the time to reply. Big hug x
Posts.Title: Pain and discomfort

Posts.Content: Hey Louise, My chemo will be FEC-T. The oncologist gave me some information yesterday which I have been reading. It all sounds pretty scary but as many people here say, things will eventually get better. I am trying to stay positive. And it will be lovely to keep in touch, I do understand what you mean. I am also very glad to have someone to talk to who's been diagnosed almost at the same time and following similar treatment, we can share lots and that is very comforting. I see you have found the link to lymphoedema... George and Jackie's replies are always very helpful. Keep strong and take care. X
Posts.Title: Pain and discomfort

Posts.Content: Emma!!! It is sooooo nice to hear form you again and best of all that you are out of your wheelchair, working with your beloved sheep again and enjoying life. Keep at it girl ;) Lots of love xx
Posts.Title: Pedal to the metal!

Posts.Content: Hi Kath, I am only starting my chemo this Tuesday (FEC-T) so can't tell you from experience but from other posts that I have read here, the best thing would be to talk to your GP or BC team and ask them to prescribe some sleeping pills. They seem to be very effective. Some other ladies have mentioned taking the steroids they give you as part of the treatment not later than 3.30-4.00pm, but I don't know if you are taking those..? Anyway, I hope you'll be able to have some rest soon. You need it. Take care xx
Posts.Title: Can't sleep.

Posts.Content: Hi there, I had three rounds of FEC and one of docetaxel that, lets just say, didn't agree with me very much. The oncologist then changed my chemo and put me on taxol. As George said, the side effects are a lot more manageable. You get some of the ones listed for docetaxel but not as severe. I've just finished six weekly rounds of taxol and apart from being increasingly tired and short of breath with the smallest effort, it has been fine. Any questions you may have, just ask. I wish you all the best. xx
Posts.Title: taxol

Posts.Content: Hi Samantha, I've no idea if that would be dangerous or not...but I can tell you that they gave me the anti-histamine first (IV) and then the dexamethasone ( IV too), prior to the paclitaxel. And yes it takes about 30 minutes. Then it's an hour for the actual paclitaxel. I hope that helps a bit...the oncologists will be able to tell you exactly why and if it is dangerous to miss one of them. The chemo nurse told me they give you piriton to prevent an allergic reaction...ah. And they also gave me anti-sickness pills before. Take care xx
Posts.Title: taxol

Posts.Content: Hi, I think the blood count doesn't tip as it does with docetaxel. It does not mean you are still not vulnerable to infection, but you won't go through nadir. They check your blood count every week just before your chemo session. That's what they did in my case. The other good thing is that you don't get the injections they usually send with docetaxel to boost up your immune system. They weren't very painful but its one less extra hassle. Take care xx
Posts.Title: taxol

Posts.Content: Hi, it takes roughly 15 minutes each, so it's 30 minutes giving them and then they start the chemo. So all in all makes it 30 minutes before you receive your chemo. It sounds confusing, I know. I hope it's clearer now ;)
Posts.Title: taxol

Posts.Content: I've been following this thread with much interest. I read the article on Friday and was very mortified by it. Thank you for all the wonderful comments Dreamthief, as always. And Jane, thank you for mentioning your nails getting stronger after 18 months. That's exactly when I finished my treatment. I was in the chemo club of April-August 2014. I've been slowly growing back my hair, learning to cope with the annoyances of taking tamoxifen, et cetera but also going back to work, enjoying life, sending my daughter to uni - she was such a star supporting me all the way through from diagnosis, surgery, chemo and radio. My finger nails are still brittle and break easily but I'm hoping they'll start getting stronger soon too. Toenails unfortunately grew back like claws. Not a nice look for sandals Another lady here said it is doable, because we have to do it. If not, then what? Lizzie, I hope things go okay for you. As someone else said, it is like childbirth. It's a different experience for everyone. But the main thing to remember is that your treatment is going to make you better in the end. Good wishes to everyone!
Posts.Title: Decca Aitkenhead in the Guardian

Posts.Content: Hello there, I am due to start my chemo (FEC) next Tuesday. I am really scared but feel a bit better reading all these posts. Thanks a lot everyone! I am preparing as best as I can following all the useful recommendations here, nevertheless it feels daunting... xx
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy

Posts.Content: Thank you, Louise. The nurse told me the same but I have always had long hair and if I am going to lose even some, I just wanted to get used to the idea by having it cut short before that happened. It seems so frivolous to be worrying about things like that but I love my hair and besides I have read in some posts here that the longer your hair is the more pain you feel in your scalp...anyway, we'll see what happens. I am also having my nails painted black this weekend with my daughter. Don't forget to do the same before you start FEC. And please keep posting, I want to know what chemo treatment they decide for you. Take care. Big hug xxx
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi Emma, I will keep the advice on mini eggs in mind ;) thank you for your support. xx
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi Anne, thank you for all those useful tips! You mentioned using the cold cap. They offered one at the hospital for me too, I was thinking I will give it a go but just want to ask if your hair must be cut very short for the first session? Mine is long and although I am aware I need to cut it, I'm not sure how short if using the cold cap. Please any advice welcome :) Thanks a lot to everyone giving support, reassurance and comfort. This site is absolutely wonderful! Love xxx
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy

Posts.Content: Thank you ladies for your replies xxx
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy

Posts.Content: I was rushing and forgot to add that I have been reading your posts and will keep my fingers crossed for you. It is knowing people like you in this site, strong, kind and generous that makes the light at the end of the tunnel seem possible. I wish you well and send you big gentle hugs. X
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi Debs, sorry, this may sound silly but have you checked the date on the letter? The same happened to me and I was going into a panic. I phoned the hospital and asked them if there had been a mistake and they said, no, it's not, the appointment is for March 2015! Could it be the same? Anyway, wishing you all the best xx

Posts.Content: Great post George & Jackie! Thank you for the information. X

Posts.Content: Keep the fight on, Emma. It is good to hear you sound so positive and that you have so many lovely friends ad family supporting you. Love and hugs, xxx

Posts.Content: Hello Emma! So glad you are feeling better! It's great to have you back here. I miss your posts and your kind words whenever someone asks for advice. I finished chemo and now waiting for my radiotherapy to start at the end of the month. I'll be watching that programme on 26th August... Best wishes and big welcome back hug xx
Posts.Title: Sheep and Cancer - now on TV!

Posts.Content: Well done you!!! Congratulations and best wishes for your surgery. xx
Posts.Title: Last chemo done, 3 x FEC and 3 x Taxatere. Done! finito!!

Posts.Content: Hi Louise, trust your medical team, they are working to get you better. Sorry you are feeling this anxious, it's only natural, but as some other ladies have said here, they need your wound to be properly healed before chemo. Thinking of you, best wishes. xxx
Posts.Title: diagnosis to chemo starting...worried

Posts.Content: That's a brilliant story, Jane. Soooo funny and so true. Humor is the best ally in troubled times. X
Posts.Title: Don't forget to laugh

Posts.Content: Hi Nonrag,  congratulations  on your new hair! Mine is growing fast too. I finished chemo in August and my head is fully covered now. I too had problems with extremely dry scalp. Someone told me to rub extra virgin olive oil every night. And it worked wonderfully! My scalp was back to normal in about one week. Try it and see ;) x
Posts.Title: extremely dry scalp
